title: Wednesday, 19th June 2019
bodyHTML:
Soundbuy Morning
Blank canvas Good morning. Happy Wednesday to everyone
11:06 am
BE11:07am

Right then. Let's get going I guess.

VV75 morning
A. M. Morning all.
SupposeToBeWorking... Morning

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's ..... yeah still not entirely sure what it is. But it's only been a decade or so, we'll work it out soon.

Irish HF guy guten morgen all
nightingale20201 morning all

undefined

Starting with the FTSE 100's biggest faller at pixel.

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 608.00, down 30.2 (-4.73%), High: 628.20, Low: 607.80, Volume: 968.52k
Soundbuy Go compare a tad lively into the close yesterday.........
PBateman @soundbuy bit fruity indeed
11:13 am
BE11:14am

UBS saying "But competition! And spending! And hang on, this thing does nothing other than getting a moped to bring you a takeaway what on earth?"

Irish HF guy Just Eat, £4.3bn market cap
Nately Loving HL's "more questions than answers" letter to Nicky Morgan. So - "We had concerns 18 months ago/we spoke to Link regarding valuations/We had tensions with Woodford/We, erm, still put the 257th of 258 funds into our Wealth 50".
BE11:14am

So, down to neutral.

BE11:15am

But with the possibility that Cat Rock wins with its activist campaign, so only neutral.

PBateman It’s a ‘platform’ BE therefore 100x multiple is the base case
Omikin hello all.
11:15 am
BE11:16am

. Much of the supportive signals we expected did not come through. Three surprises drive our more cautious view: negative trends for JE UK brand perception, a re-acceleration of UK share loss, and worrying search trends in many markets. Our main concern is that JE is not investing enough at a time when capital is flowing into the industry and customer acquisition costs are rising. We have two sources of near-term concerns: 1) our statistical work leads us to lower our 2019e UK order growth forecast to +9%, below company guidance of low to mid-teens, and 2) we are 5% below consensus on 2020e EBITDA, as JE will likely need to invest to contain share loss. Signs of improved execution and a margin reset with a new CEO would be important factors for us to turn more constructive on the name.

Irish HF guy @Nately, I was very interested in the liquidity profile provided by Link to the FCA. Can you believe they had 8% of assets in the 1-7 day liquidity bucket only, and they had an escalation point of curiously that amount, with a 5% red limit.. It should have been 50% or at least 33%. This is truly very poor liquidity management by Link on the LF Woodford Equity Income Fund
cracklenpop @nightingale Tesco was meant to be tackling the discounters with Jack's but little mention of that at yesterday's CMD, instead M&S/Simply Food now in its sights...with its Finest range?
BE11:17am

So, the UBS evidence lab thing -- which seems to be a private ONS given the amount it's cited in their research -- suggests deteriorating brand perception and accelerating share erosion in terms of consumer spend.

BE11:18am

Which isn't wholly surprising with a listed company that's competing against two private, VC subsidised competitors that are prepared to run at a loss to gain market share.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Therefore, bath required on margin.

BE11:18am

We think that JE can grow uEBITDA to £220m in 2019e (5% below consensus at £230m), but in a context of share loss in most markets. A margin reset is needed in our view for Just Eat to keep up with competitors' aggressive spend. Our analysis suggests £100m EBITDA in 2019e would put JE's pace of customer acquisition in line with competitors in key markets including Europe and the UK.

BE11:19am

On its current path, JE is set to lose its #1 position in France and Spain in our view, as the pace of customer acquisition for its key competitors seems much higher than JE's. Like DHER or iFood in 2018, we think JE needs to upgrade its investment plans in Europe if it wants to maintain leadership.

Nately @Irish - hadn't seen that, but when I read the other day that "1/3rd of the fund will take 6-12 months to liquidate", my first thought was "how much longer will the other 2/3rds take" :)
Patience @BE - in Norwich significant that Chinese and Curry takeaways rarely use Just Eat - hire freelancers to leaflet-drop menus and deliver orders.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

However, as to the activist angle, Canada and Brazil alone are worth 450p per share at 1.4x EV/GMV

Patience Just Eat mainly used by new outlets.
BE11:21am

Against 0.6x 2020 for the group.

rw42 Happy to order from anywhere that lets me type in my address on phone/PC rather than struggle to be understood on the phone here, no brand loyalty whatsoever.
red surely uber eat comes in and offers discount to put to bed just eat?
BE11:22am

So, stick around for the breakup. Get out when it becomes clear that the cash for the breakup will be given to IT people and advertising agencies rather than you.

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,602, up 3 (+0.07%), High: 4,617, Low: 4,500, Volume: 284.33k

Surging 0.07p on a Q1 IMS that says "ooh, Brexit" mostly.

nightingale20201 @cracklenpop...yes...I am confused with TSCO strategy ....for sure...high end that could generate 7%/8% margin (double that of the current run rate)...why not ..but what is the capex required...
MassimoJ Morning, I know you've mentioned Saga but if I could also put into the request category please
BE11:25am

L4L group sales weaken to -3.7% in Q1 from -0.6% in Q4.

AMALtd morning
11:25 am
BE11:26am

But that's where the consensus was already, so the most you'll see is a slight tightening of the range.

BE11:26am

And there's a £2bn tender offer and buyback, offering any shareholders who want out a ready buyer. So, it's dead money for the moment. Here's Canaccord.

BE11:27am

Whitbread reported -3.7% UK L4L sales (accommodation -4.6%, F&B -2.1%), a marked
deterioration from 4Q19 where UK L4L sales were -0.6%; the company had warned at
the prelims that current trading had deteriorated. The regions performed worse than

London and business custom performed worse than leisure with the short-lead, mid-
week business traveller becoming a scarcer species. We cut our forecasts at the prelims

stage and we leave our forecasts unchanged. We assume a 3% decline in RevPar to
£47.46 for FY20E and a 2% decline to £46.51 for FY21E. Every one percent change in
RevPar impacts EBIT by £12m-£15m. We assume that lower achieved room rates, rather
than occupancy, account for most of the decline. Whitbread is determined to keep its
hotels busy rather than protecting price, following a strategy that is similar to the airlines.
Whitbread's cost saving initiatives are helping to protect margins and profitability. At the
prelims, it set out a new target of £220m of savings over the next three years, to be split
£120m of opex and £100m of capex savings. This is on top of the £150m delivered in
the last three years. Whitbread has a £1.6bn cost base and expects to offset £40m-
£50m of the anticipated £70m of cost headwinds in FY20. Whitbread will implement the
new IFRS16 accounting standard at the interim stage and we will follow suit.
Whitbread has trimmed UK new room guidance to 3k-3.5k from 3k-4k; and will delay
extensions rather than new builds. It still expects to open +2k rooms in Germany this
year. It will continue to invest in growing its estate in both the UK and Germany despite
any deterioration in conditions, arguing that any cyclical change should not impact the
structural opportunity. To this end, it has retained £300m to acquire the German hotels
at end February 2020 and a further £500m for other opportunities. It is fortunate that it
has a strong balance sheet that allows it to be so far-sighted.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

At yesterday's close, Whitbread is trading on a PE of 20.1x, and EV/EBITDA of 10.7x and
FCF yield of 5.4% for FY20E, changing to 16.9x, 10.7x and 6.3% respectively for FY21E.
Our 4850p target price is based on FY21E as FY20E is still a transitional year for its
capital structure; we use a cautious c.11.5x EBITDA to value Premier Inn and 9.0x for the
pub restaurants. Whitbread's valuation is under-pinned by c£5bn of freehold assets and
a good defensive earnings track record. Potential buyers could include InterContinental
Hotels and Marriott or private equity.

Irish HF guy @Nately, at 30 April 2019 8% 1-7 days, 29% 8-30 days, 32% 30-180 days and 33% 180days +in 30 June 2018 it was 21% 1-7 days, 24% 8-30 days, 30% 30-180 days and 25% 180days + Crazy...

Saga!

FY "broadly" in line

Omikin Whitbread try to appeal to the punters with kids market but really fail to appeal. I always give the kids the choice and they never willingly choose Whitbread, even though they have a soft-play area.
Irish HF guy So Woodford had only 8% of NAV in 1-7 day liquidity bucket and they had redemptions of 8.2% of NAV. Amazing. This fund is going to be suspended for at least 6 months in my opinion!

BE11:31am

(Is "inventory" the right word for insurance? You know what I mean.)

Soundbuy @STBW - hmmm.............never know.........divided nation apparently

That's led to travel and pet insurance and stuff like that falling off, while home and motor seem to be stabilising. The result is a headline 8% fall in policies, but a lot of churn.

Nately Thanks @Irish - far longer than 6m IMO, Woody needs the fees on it to keep WIM afloat, and will keep using the "looking to float some unlisteds" excuse. The fund is dead as soon as it reopens based on running redemptions.

Forecasts aren't really changing and there's nothing new on strategy, so the share price fall looks to be on the increased risk of H2 not coming through ....

Soundbuy Saga - will this be a never ending story......

BE11:34am

.... and with the cruise ship peak debt thing happening over the next few years, that amplifies equity moves.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:34am

Saga states trading is broadly in line with expectations in the quarter as it rolls out its new ‘back to basics’ affinity broking strategy. There are no changes to downgraded 2019/20 targets outlined at the full-year results. Insurance broking is seeing some momentum as new products are rolled out across the core Motor & Home book and Cruise bookings are resilient. There is some weakness in the small Tour operations, but the main catalyst is Cruises and the success of the new ship launch in July. It is still early days, the shares remain undervalued (P/E 5x 2019E), whilst the search for a new CEO has already kicked off.

J L Hello All, not been about for a while, hope everyone is Ok. Thanks BE for a decade of information.
Irish HF guy @Nately, the fund is dead as the liquidity profile of it is shocking. What is even worse is that the Link Liquidity risk parameters would seem to have been tailored not to have a liquidity event if you read the FCA response to Parliament https://bit.ly/2FngGgy
BE11:35am

The core Saga-branded Motor & Home policies were flat yoy (564k), helped by slightly improved retention rates as the company rolls out its new three-year fixed policies. As of mid-June, 60k of three-year fixed policies have been sold, of which half is new business and in line with Saga’s assumptions. There is however weakness in Motorbike & Travel insurance, driving overall policy volumes down 6% for the period to 753k as Saga prioritises rate over volume. The gross margins for the Motor & Home broking are in line with the target range, suggesting broker margin pressure is in line with expectations.
The Travel business is mixed, with the Tour operations (a modest contributor to revenue and earnings) seeing revenue pressure driven by discounting (revenues -4% slightly below -3% expectations in April). However, Cruise booking are proving to be resilient. Around 86% of targeted bookings for 2019/20 departures have been made for the first new cruise ship Spirit of Discovery,
whilst forward bookings for 2020/21 are broadly on track (31% for the two new ships). Cruise will make a small loss in 1H 19 (£3m), in line with the business plan, as the new ship is launched and the old one decommissioned. Finally, the membership scheme (1.1m members) is seeing growing engagement (+15% in the past two months to 208k), which suggests the new marketing campaigns are starting to have an impact. This is very much core to Saga’s strategy in our view, with membership engagement the key driver for improving the revenue base. Whilst it is still early days since the April profit warning, there seems to be some improved momentum in the business and the next catalyst will be the success of the launch of the new ship in July, with each new vessel targeted to contribute an annual £40m of EBITDA in the coming years, materially reducing Saga’s reliance on the insurance broking business.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

And JPMorgan.

BE11:37am

Trading overall seen as "broadly in line". Saga states that it is making progress against the strategy outlined in early April, with Insurance delivering in line with expectation. Saga states that it has seen an uptick in the proportion of new business sold direct (60%) vs. (50% for FY19), with over half of new direct customers opting for the new 3-year fix product. Travel has been more difficult, with political uncertainty resulting in a very competitive market backdrop.

Irish HF guy @BE, it has been more than a decade, the Lehman crisis of 2008 was covered here as was Northern Rock crisis in 2007.
LeoInvestorUK Suggestions of regulations over Cruise refunds and worse rates for loyal insurance customers (across the industry) cannot be good for Sage.
JimboRock Why do SAGA persist with the over 50 strategy?
BE11:38am

Insurance delivering in line with new plans. Saga states that its gross margins per policy in Home and Motor are in line with the target range [£71-74], and claims trends in the underwriter are in line with expectations. 60,000 3-year fix products have now been sold [c11% of Home/Motor policies], of which 30,000 relate to new business. Saga states that the new strategy continues to be rolled out on a test-and-learn basis.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Travel seeing increasingly competitive conditions. Saga states that its Tour Operations in particular have seen pressure, with booked revenue for the FY down 4% YoY and competitive discounting having an impact on margins. Cruise bookings have been more resilient, with bookings for FY20/21 described as “broadly on track". A significant step up in marketing activities is expected in the next few months to coincide with the launch of the first new cruise ship.
Saga also states that Cruise will contribute an operating loss of £3m in H1 (in line with plans), which we believe will overall result in a slight second half weighting to group PBT.

LeoInvestorUK Apparently Cruise companies are supposed to refund the whole cost of the trip less their losses when cancelled due to illness etc. but they do not.
SupposeToBeWorking... @BE @IrishHF It's a shame the old transcripts from 2007/8 are lost/deleted?
red @JimboRockcos nobody under that age would be seen dead on those cruise ships
BE11:38am

And Numis.

MassimoJ Thanks for Saga, BE
BE11:39am

Trading is described as broadly in line with expectations, with good early progress from newly launched insurance products and cruise bookings broadly in line with targets. The tours business is seeing challenging conditions although this is relatively small in the group context. The key motor and home insurance businesses appear to be trading in line with rebased targets set out at the finals in April. There is no comment on expected group profit for the year so we feel comfortable Saga remains on track for an outcome within the previous target range of £105-120m, albeit the worsening in tours probably means it is now more likely profit will be towards the lower end of the range. At the bottom end of the guidance range the shares currently trade on a P/E of 4.7x and a yield of 10.9% (based guidance payout of around 50%).

Stephen Schwarzman, one of America’s richest businessmen, has given Oxford university its largest single donation in modern history by providing it with £150m, it was announced on Wednesday.

The gift will fund the construction of a new hub that will bring together the university’s humanities faculties in one place for the first time, plus an institute focused on the ethical questions around artificial intelligence.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Intended disposals/exits not unexpected, but scale of proceeds key to support longer term business model. In Kier’s strategic review the group indicated the decision to sell or exit from Kier Living (affordable housing), Property (nonspeculative mixed use developments), Environmental Services and Facilities Management. These businesses we forecast to contribute c20% sales and c30% of EBITA (ex corporate costs) in FY19. Of these we believe Kier Living is likely to prove the easiest to sell. This business had a NTAV of c£120m in FY18 (excluding c £60m of other land which Kier will retain), and management indicate it should see the benefit of not just proceeds from the asset sale but it should also bring both a £35m reduction in its use of reverse factoring (which we include in our net debt calculation) and a c£50m improvement in working capital. Kier indicates it is also considering a disposal of the Property business, which with greater than 20% ROCE could see meaningful interest. However, while many housebuilders have looked to increase their exposure into this ‘partnership’ market in recent years, the indication from Kier’s management that it will look to scale down capital invested from c£184m in FY18 to c£100m by FY20 we believe investors may interpret as implying any sale could be more complex and time consuming to execute. With managed exits of Environmental Services and Facilities Management targeted (in line with our expectations given the EBIT of c-£8m and c£0m EBIT, respectively, in FY18) we believe Kier investors will ascribe negligible net proceeds.

A. M. @Excel: ok, so is oxford a for-profit academic institute?
Patience @red - supply of goods and/or services in exchange for money. Can you improve on this?
wayneJ Re Kier - there was a lot of stuff previously on 'reverse factoring' - any sense of the scale of it - and how much working capital does the business need to run 'normally'?

Basically, from here, Kier needs to pull in traditional style contracts providing actual cash that will give customers the confidence to give it raditional style contracts providing actual cash.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 9.76, down 0.242 (-2.42%), High: 9.96, Low: 9.65, Volume: 643.10k
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 441.16, down 16.34 (-3.57%), High: 457.10, Low: 431.80, Volume: 5.94m
11:55 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 882.60, down 18 (-2.00%), High: 898.40, Low: 868.00, Volume: 1.11m
BE11:56am

Upshot is that Lufthansa's profit warning is a canary rather than a ..... um .......... dodo.

BE11:56am

The problem is demand: With the March quarter results, European low-cost carriers and tour operators offered quite cautious revenue commentary. With its 17 June profit warning, Lufthansa flagged very weak short-haul revenue trends in Q2, markedly worse than it described at its end-April Q1 report. This comes despite the benefit of Easter and European capacity growth of only 4%, the lowest seen in Europe since the Global Financial crisis. Indeed, airline supply has only recently tightened with the 737 Max grounding. We conclude the problem is thus not excessive supply, but rapidly weakening demand. We think this is primarily driven by consumer confidence, with environmental sensitivities and the memory of last year’s hot summer playing supporting roles.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

So cheap flights to Europe! Escape this dismal, damp little rock. All good news.

BE11:57am

Europe today, tomorrow the world! All carriers under our coverage have spoken with confidence of trading on long-haul routes, with the North Atlantic being flagged as clearly robust. We think the longer lead time of long-haul bookings compared to short haul mean that consumer trends will follow with a lag to long haul. We also expect the weakening global trade environment will in due course impact long-haul premium traffic.

AK any reasons behing the sharp rally of NMC health ysday and today ?
wayneJ @BE - surely the risk of complexity also impacts travel within Europe right now - eg during the booking season of late last year who knew if the UK was in or out?
BE11:58am

In terms of recs:

Blank canvas Willie Walsh buying 200 half-price Boeing 737 Maxs must have seemed like a good idea in Paris yesterday
11:58 am
BE11:58am

We downgrade Air France-KLM and Finnair to Hold from Buy, and EasyJet and IAG to Reduce from Hold, leaving Aegean as our sole Buy, with five Holds and four Reduce ratings across our European airline coverage. We adjust our estimates on the assumption of lower unit revenues, mitigated by a lower working kerosene price of USD 620/MT (previously USD680/MT). We also adjust our WACC assumptions across our coverage, adopting Bloomberg 10-year betas and adjusting country risk premia to the blended country mix of each airline’s operations.

BE12:05pm

Interim Results, Revenue +82% to £41.6m tracking slightly ahead of full year expectations. 2019 outlook in line for c. 75% revenue growth with LBITDA in line with consensus. Acquisition of Thoughtonomy for up to £80m.

The robotic process automation software and services specialist reports its interim results for FY2019 (October year-end), confirming strong revenue momentum tracking slightly ahead of full year expectations in terms of growth. Revenue grew by 82% to £41.6m (prior H1: £22.9m), adjusted LBITDA loss of £34.0m on continued investment (which is 44% of the full year consensus LBITDA), with the company prioritising investment for scale and growth. As usual, operating cash outflow ran ahead of EBITDA reflecting positive working capital requirements (customers typically paying annually up front), at £18.9m. Net cash stood at £129.4m despite174% growth in Sales & Marketing headcount since 1H18 to support growth and improve reach.

Sitting behind the revenue performance was significant growth in the number of software deals with new and existing customers. The total number of software deals secured during year was 911 (prior H1: 559), up by 63%, consisting of 349 customer additions (prior H1: 349), up by 57%, and 496 upsells (prior H1: 298) upsells, up by 66%. At the end of 2018, the total customer base stood at 1,337 (prior H1: 700), up by 91%.

Prism has also announced the acquisition of Thoughtonomy for aggregate consideration of up to £80m, enhances cloud capabilities and directly addresses the mid-tier market. In the remaining three months of the Group’s financial year, it is anticipated that Thoughtonomy will increase revenues by up to £3m and increase EBITDA losses by up to £2m.

The Board is said to be confidence in the outlook based on the exit monthly recurring revenue, and as a result, expects the Group’s underlying 2019 performance, excluding the acquisition of Thoughtonomy, will be in line with the expectations outlined at its trading update in November 2018 and reiterated at the full year results in January. Current consensus for FY2019 revenue is £96.7m (ShoreCap £98.6m). Adjusted EBITDA loss is expected to be around £77m. We provisionally expect to leave our estimates unchanged.

At 1,858p, and EV/Sales of c14x (FY2019F), the shares are up 70% year to date and 50% since our note Blue Prism: In it to win it (Feb. 2019). Additionally, the prevailing market cap is at a c60% discount to the mean of the recent private-equity backed valuations of its two closest RPA (Robotic Process Automation) peers, namely UiPath ($7bn) and Automation Anywhere ($3bn). We therefore continue to see the shares as both rationally and attractively valued with good upside potential over the medium term driven by strong equity rating compression.
